_prev_prog_3.Description: Propylene is stored as a liquid in a vessel built to pressure vessel code.  The vessel is interconnected to a refrigeration unit which utilizes the propylene to reduce temperature to -300 F.  This cryogenic process separates the syngas into carbon monoxide and hydrogen, which is consumed in other processes.  The storage vessel utilizes pressure relief devices and local LEL detection for protection.  The portions of the unit operations at cryogenic temperatures utilize materials designed for use at this temperature.  A firewater system with hydrant monitors allows this system to mitigate leaks.  The unit has a DCS control system which provides the operators with information, warnings and alarms that ensure safe operation.  Operators are trained to follow standard operation procedures that ensure safe operation during normal, abnormal and emergency situations.  LyondellBasell participates in a complex Emergency Response Team which allows trained responders to handle fire and hazardous materials response.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 

LyondellBasell is committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is inherent to an accidental release prevention program in place that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at LyondellBasell La Porte. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If such a release does occur, our trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release. We are also coordinated with Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) which provides additional emergency response expertise.



2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled 

LyondellBasell produces several final products at the La Porte facility including methanol and syngas (which is a mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen). We have two regulated substances present at LyondellBasell La Porte in quantities greater than or equal to their threshold quantities (as listed below).

Propylene

1,3-Butadiene



3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

LyondellBasell La Porte has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68. This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA-58 Standard, (1967 Edition). Several processes at LyondellBasell La Porte are subject to the OSHA PSM standard under 29 CFR 1910.119.



The following sections briefly describe the elements of our release prevention program that are in place at LyondellBasell La Porte. Regarding Process Safety Information, LyondellBasell La Porte maintains a record of written safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. Regarding Process Hazard Analysis, LyondellBas

ell La Porte conducts studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The methodologies used to carry out these analyses are unit Process Hazard Analysis. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated on an as needed basis. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.



Operating Procedures

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, LyondellBasell La Porte maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved with the processes.



Training

LyondellBasell La Porte has a training program in place to ensure that employees that are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. New employees receive basic training in process operations followed by on-the-job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.



Mechanical Integrity

LyondellBasell La Porte carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper functions. Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Management of C

hange

Written procedures are in place at LyondellBasell La Porte to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at LyondellBasell La Porte. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits

LyondellBasell La Porte conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented. These audits are carried out at least every 5 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner. 



Incident Investigation

LyondellBasell La Porte investigates incidents that have resulted in, or could reasonably result in, an employee injury or a significant release of a hazardous material. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.



Employee Participation

LyondellBasell La Porte believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility implementation to the RMP rule information resulting from process hazard analyses.



Contractors

Our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activiti

es. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out. LyondellBasell La Porte has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related the contractor's work and the processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur. Contractor post evaluations are also conducted to ensure compliance with LyondellBasell safety and health procedures.



4. Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases in the past five years that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage.



5. Emergency Response Plan

LyondellBasell La Porte carries a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes emergency response activities including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas. To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the p1an is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response. The La Porte Police Department is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which our emergency plan has been coordinated.



6. Emergency Response Team

LyondellBasell La Porte has gone above and beyond the normal safety requirements to provide employees with a safe working environment. One program that enhances our ability to respond to emergencies is our Emergency Response Program. Members of the Emergency Response Team (ERT) undergo training that includes classroom and on-the-job training as well as regular emergency drills. A highly trained and confiden

t ERT can limit damage during an emergency event, but more importantly prompt emergency response can prevent more serious accidents from occurring. Our teams regularly attend some of the best training programs available, in particular, the programs conducted at Texas A&M University.





Future changes to improve safety: The plant has planned improvements to alarm systems, safety interlocks systems, and level control systems to improve safety at the site.
